question: <image 1> Which of the following was another common criticism of Andrew Carnegie?
options: ['As an immigrant, Carnegie had no right to own controlling interests in major American industries.', 'Carnegie did nothing to prevent the use of violence against his workers when they asked for better wages and working conditions.', 'Carnegie was seen as the epitome of American success, but he was not even the richest man in America.', "Too much of Carnegie's philanthropic efforts were concentrated on his homeland of Scotland, denying Americans the benefits of his charity."]
description: The image is a political cartoon titled "Forty-Millionaire Carnegie in his Great Double Role," published in The Saturday Globe on July 9, 1892. The cartoon depicts Andrew Carnegie in two contrasting roles. On one side, Carnegie is shown holding a notice that reads "Wages Reduced 20 per cent," symbolizing his role as a ruthless employer who reduces wages. On the other side, Carnegie is depicted giving away money, specifically $5000, representing his philanthropic efforts. The cartoon highlights the duality of Carnegie's character, showing how he could simultaneously exploit workers while also engaging in charitable acts. The caption at the bottom of the cartoon reads: "As the tight-fisted employer he reduces wages that he may play philanthropist and give away libraries, etc." This suggests that Carnegie's philanthropy was funded by the exploitation of his workers.
